repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Use more compact formatting and re-use repeated screen states.

comment_data.body: Should still use `expect { }` syntax (the function takes several named args, not a single table arg)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -23,86 +28,59 @@ local function test_cmdline(linegrid)
 
   it('works', function()
     feed(':')
-    screen:expect {
-      grid = [[
-      ^                         |
-      {1:~                        }|*3
-                               |
-    ]],
+    screen:expect({
+      grid = empty_grid,
       cmdline = { {
         firstc = ':',
         content = { { '' } },
         pos = 0,
       } },
-    }
+    })
 
     feed('sign')
-    screen:expect {
-      grid = [[
-      ^                         |
-      {1:~                        }|*3
-                               |
-    ]],
+    screen:expect({

comment_data.body: Not worth it for `s1` when there are so few repetitions

Do you mean to omit the surrounding `()`? How does that better indicate the function takes several named args?

I added them because we seem to prefer surrounding parentheses in general (and may want to enforce it at some point)? Previous discussion: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31441#discussion_r1869476420.

comment_data.body: Worth what? What do you lose by representing it like this? In my mind it only reduces cognitive load to determine that there are 2 identical screen states after some intermediate steps.
You need to scroll upwards to find the variable

Yes well what's actually being tested here is the ext_cmdline state, it not being included directly in the call helps to highlight that. Having to scroll up for a grid state we don't really care about doesn't seem too big of a deal to me.

But happy to change this back when I rebase this (and the rest of the changes _are_ wanted).

the general style _is_ to use `expect { }` and has always been. as stated in the linked thread this is what is directly enforced by `screen:snapshot_util()` already. 

Hacking things away from this output for the sake to be different in individual PRs does not make things more "consistent" or "general"

comment_data.body:
because the _exception_ of using a variable breaks the usual flow of screen tests, and indicates the code is special is some positively meaningful way, like perhaps taking a parametric function argument. It can be worth it when it saves a _lot_ of repeated screens, but should not be used haphazardly just to save 5-6 lines which easily can be eyed to be identical (which is just _one_ of multiple possible reasons a variable could used). 

Code that you can "not care" about should follow the surrounding patterns, not stick out. It will also make tooling to systematically refactor screen expectations (like changing the color scheme in bulk) harder to use as well.

> the general style is to use expect { } and has always been. as stated in the linked thread this is what is directly enforced by screen:snapshot_util() already.

The thing is that that already is no longer the case, as stated in the linked thread... But if you feel strongly about this some previous PRs should be reverted instead.

> Hacking things away from this output for the sake to be different in individual PRs does not make things more "consistent" or "general"

The formatting used here matches what is spit out by `screen:snapshot_util()` now, so obviously individual PRs "hacking" towards that _will_ make it more consistent over time.

comment_data.body:
for reference, I wrote this as a summary the last time we did a _consistent_ major refactor (the enabling of stylua in the first place): https://github.com/JohnnyMorganz/StyLua/issues/829 . So, yes the part of "correcting" the line breaks in snapshot_util() to match what stylua does for now, did make sense. However, when stylua was enabled #26398 it already supported our existing and fully consistent style of brackets, so there was no need to change that. 

Unless I missed some other discussion, I just don't see how pointless churn in unrelated PRs back and forth helps towards consistency or readability, thus I just simply suggested to avoid that here and in further PR:s:p

comment_data.body:
> it already supported our existing and fully consistent style of brackets, so there was no need to change that.

As I mentioned before, it is _not_ fully consistent in `/test`, and our _more_ scrutinized `/runtime/lua` consistently uses call parentheses (as far as I could tell last time). I changed it to match that.
